title: Revision of the Treaties – Transitional measures concerning the composition of the European Parliament: REPORT on the draft protocol amending Protocol No 36 on transitional provisions concerning the composition of the European Parliament for the rest of the 2009-2014 parliamentary term: the European Parliament’s opinion (Article 48(3) of the EU Treaty)
background: The Lisbon Treaty's entry into force (1 December 2009) altered European Parliament seat allocations from 736 (Nice Treaty) to 751 MEPs. The 2009 elections occurred under Nice rules, creating a discrepancy. Protocol No. 36 required adjustment to temporarily accommodate 18 additional MEPs from 12 states without mid-term reductions. The Parliament will discuss amending Protocol No. 36 to enable transitional composition measures for the 2009-2014 parliamentary term.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the immediate seating of all 18 additional MEPs through direct elections, aligning with their commitment to democratic legitimacy and institutional balance.  
EPP applauds the insistence on simultaneous integration of new Members to preserve fair national representation, reflecting their principle of equal citizenship across the Union.  
EPP urges accelerated ratification of Protocol No 36 amendments while maintaining opposition to national parliamentary appointments, reinforcing their dedication to direct voter mandates.  
EPP accepts the exceptional intergovernmental conference mechanism as a pragmatic solution but emphasizes this must not circumvent future convention processes for Treaty changes.  
EPP proposes harmonizing Member States' electoral procedures to prevent similar transitional delays, enhancing Lisbon Treaty implementation without opposing the issue's core timeline.

GUE_NGL completely disputes any protocol enabling unelected MEPs, as this violates core democratic principles of direct representation  
GUE_NGL rejects transitional measures allowing appointed parliamentarians, directly contradicting Treaty requirements for elections under the 1976 Act  
This proposal dangerously undermines legitimacy by permitting non-elected members, despite 2007 precedents requiring immediate elections for new accession states  
The issue's tolerance for intergovernmental negotiations conflicts with GUE_NGL's absolute stance against indirect selection mechanisms  
GUE_NGL condemns the Council's failure to ensure simultaneous direct elections across all member states as required by Lisbon Treaty obligations

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the implementation of the Lisbon Treaty’s provisions on its composition, emphasizing the need to adjust the number of Members (MEPs) from 736 under the Nice Treaty to 751 as stipulated by the Lisbon Treaty. It noted that the 2009 elections were held under the Nice framework, resulting in 736 MEPs, but the Lisbon Treaty’s entry into force on 1 December 2009 necessitated adding 18 MEPs from 12 Member States, temporarily increasing the total to 754 until the end of the 2009-2014 term. This temporary overage required amending Protocol No 36 to accommodate transitional measures. The Parliament stressed that all 18 additional MEPs must take their seats simultaneously to preserve institutional balance, urging Member States to expedite their election processes. It criticized the Council’s delay in enabling the timely seating of these MEPs and opposed indirect election via national parliaments, favoring direct elections under the 1976 Act. While reluctantly accepting an intergovernmental conference to address transitional measures, it insisted these must be exceptional and not set precedents. The resolution also highlighted the need for future decisions on Parliament’s composition to account for potential new Member States and instructed its President to communicate the resolution to relevant EU institutions and national parliaments.

title: Commissioner hearings: lessons to be taken from the 2014 process: REPORT on procedures and practices regarding Commissioner hearings, lessons to be taken from the 2014 process
background: Following the 2014 European Commission hearings, concerns emerged over nomination timelines, gender representation in candidate selections, financial interest disclosures, and hearing procedures under EU treaties and prior parliamentary resolutions. The Parliament will discuss optimizing Commissioner-designate evaluation processes, focusing on procedures for enhancing transparency, gender balance, and accountability.

stances.stance:
SD entirely promotes the issue’s mandate for gender parity in Commissioner nominations, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to institutional equality and its demand that member states propose both male and female candidates to achieve a gender-balanced College.  
SD perfectly aligns with the expansion of financial scrutiny to include family members’ interests, a critical enhancement of accountability that reflects SD’s unwavering prioritization of ethical governance and anti-corruption frameworks.  
SD unequivocally supports leveraging social media to deepen citizen engagement during hearings, advancing SD’s strategic goal of democratizing EU processes and ensuring public participation aligns with parliamentary transparency standards.  
SD entirely promotes procedural rigor in hearings, including extended durations for Vice-Presidents and fixed nomination deadlines, which effectively advance SD’s vision of a merit-based, scrutiny-driven Commission appointment system.  
SD applauds the call for periodic post-appointment performance reviews, resonating perfectly with SD’s manifesto pledge to enforce continuous accountability for EU executives beyond their initial confirmation.

ECR rejects the issue’s procedural framework for failing to dismantle coordinators’ disproportionate control over hearings, contradicting ECR’s demand for direct MEP questioning rights.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the omission of binding mechanisms to insulate the Commission from Troika influence, a non-negotiable priority for ECR’s vision of institutional independence.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of citizen engagement by relying on passive social media strategies rather than formalizing public input channels as ECR advocates.  
ECR condemns the issue’s gender parity system as bureaucratic overreach inconsistent with member states’ sovereign nomination rights.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of enhancing democratic legitimacy and transparency through public hearings of Commissioners-designate, emphasizing their role in assessing candidates' qualifications, priorities, and suitability for their portfolios. It called for gender equality in the Commission’s composition, criticizing the 2014 imbalance where larger Member States predominantly proposed male candidates, and recommended each Member State submit one male and one female candidate to ensure a gender-balanced College. The resolution proposed procedural improvements, including setting deadlines for Member States to nominate candidates, expanding written questionnaires to seven questions, allowing immediate follow-up questions to improve scrutiny, and extending hearings for Vice-Presidents beyond three hours due to their broader responsibilities. It stressed the need to strengthen financial transparency by requiring Commissioners-designate to disclose family members’ interests and broadening the Committee on Legal Affairs’ scrutiny to identify conflicts of interest. The resolution highlighted the 2014 hearings’ increased public engagement via social media and urged leveraging such platforms to involve citizens. It addressed structural challenges, such as aligning portfolios with parliamentary committees’ remits and ensuring fair evaluation processes, including replacement candidates’ hearings under equal conditions. Specific concerns were raised about last-minute portfolio changes, notably in Transport, which disrupted fair assessment. The Parliament also advocated periodic reviews of Commissioners’ post-appointment performance and stricter adherence to deadlines for publishing evaluation statements within 24 hours after hearings. Overall, the resolution sought to institutionalize gender parity, enhance accountability, and improve the rigor and inclusivity of the Commission approval process.

title: Amendments to Parliament's Rules of Procedure: REPORT on amendments to Parliament’s Rules of Procedure affectingChapters 1 and 4 of Title I; Chapter 3 of Title V; Chapters 4 and 5 of Title VII; Chapter 1 of Title VIII; Title XII; Title XIV and Annex II
background: A 2018 European Court ruling on parliamentary disciplinary measures and evolving transparency standards prompted the Committee on Constitutional Affairs to propose amendments to the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure. The Parliament will discuss revisions addressing transparency obligations, political group formation criteria, and alignment with legal frameworks governing parliamentary conduct and institutional accountability.

stances.stance:
SD strongly promotes the transparency reforms mandating lobbyist registration and public disclosure of meetings, aligning perfectly with their commitment to open governance and accountability.  
SD entirely promotes the amendments requiring political groups to demonstrate genuine ideological cohesion, preventing artificial alliances that undermine parliamentary legitimacy.  
SD proposes amending Rule 11(3e) to prohibit secret voting on transparency-related provisions, ensuring alignment with public accountability principles.  
SD applauds the enforceable behavioral protocols for Members, particularly the Code’s expanded accountability measures, which mirror their 2024 ethical governance manifesto.  
SD approves mandatory consultation mechanisms for committee decisions, addressing concerns about unilateral leadership actions while preserving procedural efficiency.

GUE_NGL partly promotes the transparency amendments in Chapters 1 and 4 of Title I, endorsing mandatory lobbyist meeting disclosures to counter public distrust.  
GUE_NGL requests revision of Amendment 86 and 87 in Title XIV, demanding explicit criteria to prevent arbitrary politicization of procedural decisions.  
GUE_NGL opposes Annex II modifications establishing subjective "political affinity" tests for group formation, citing violations of pluralism principles.  
GUE_NGL warns that bureaucratic procedural changes in Title VII Chapter 5 risk diminishing legislative scrutiny capacities contrary to democratic accountability.  
GUE_NGL insists future amendments must prohibit supranational power concentration aligning with corporate interests rather than popular sovereignty.

resolution: The European Parliament raised amendments to its Rules of Procedure, with most changes taking effect on the first day of the next part-session, while specific provisions—including the second subparagraph of Rule 11(3e), points 6 and 7 of the Code of appropriate behavior for Members, and amendments to Rules 196 and 204—were deferred until the opening of the first part-session following the 2019 elections. The resolution mandated the President to inform the Council and Commission of these updates, ensuring alignment with procedural reforms ahead of the new legislative term. The adjustments aimed to enhance governance standards and behavioral protocols for Members, prioritizing timely implementation of core changes while delaying certain measures to post-election continuity.

title: A comprehensive European Union framework on endocrine disruptors: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the negotiations with the Council and Commission on the legislative proposal for a regulation on the European Parliament’s right of inquiry
background: Following the Treaty of Lisbon granting the European Parliament legislative initiative on inquiry procedures, prolonged negotiations since 2014 between EU institutions over updating the 1995 framework have stalled due to unresolved legal and institutional concerns. The Parliament will discuss challenges in adopting a regulation on its investigative powers and interinstitutional cooperation under the special legislative procedure.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue’s insistence on legal action through the Court of Justice to enforce institutional cooperation obligations, aligning perfectly with GREEN_EFA’s commitment to transparent governance.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on democratic accountability through robust inquiry tools, which effectively advances the party’s priority of combating corporate environmental negligence in chemical regulation.  
GREEN_EFA approves the integration of lessons from PANA and EMIS committees, proposing to amend Article 4 to explicitly include public access to anonymized inquiry findings as a transparency enhancement.  
GREEN_EFA endorses invoking the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making, urging expansion of witness testimony provisions to cover subcontractors in chemical supply chains.  
GREEN_EFA fully backs escalating the issue to EU leaders, stressing this aligns with their manifesto pledge to strengthen parliamentary oversight of endocrine disruptor policies.

ECR entirely conflicts with the issue's legal action proposal through the Court of Justice, viewing it as an unconstitutional power grab that bypasses national sovereignty principles.  
ECR opposes the reliance on the Interinstitutional Agreement for structured negotiations, arguing it imposes supranational bureaucracy inconsistent with subsidiarity.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of institutional balance by demanding unilateral parliamentary access to sensitive documents without member state oversight.  
ECR rejects the characterization of Council resistance as undemocratic, maintaining that scrutiny mechanisms must respect national governments' constitutional roles.  
This issue disregards ECR's core principle that inquiry powers should remain decentralized to prevent EU overreach into member states' jurisdictional domains.

resolution: The European Parliament raised significant concerns over the Council and Commission’s obstruction of efforts to adopt a regulation strengthening its investigative powers under Article 226 TFEU, which mandates a special legislative procedure requiring their consent. Despite over four years of informal negotiations, working documents, and legal consultations between the institutions’ services, the Council and Commission refused to engage in formal political discussions to resolve key disagreements, including institutional resistance to granting Parliament robust inquiry tools such as witness summons and document access. The resolution criticized this as a breach of sincere interinstitutional cooperation (Article 13(2) TEU) and democratic accountability, emphasizing Parliament’s constitutional role in overseeing the executive. It highlighted lessons from recent inquiry committees (PANA on financial crimes and EMIS on emissions fraud), which underscored the need for updated investigative rules. Parliament urged its President to escalate the issue to EU leaders, proposed legal action via the Court of Justice to enforce cooperation obligations, and called on political parties and *Spitzenkandidaten* to publicly support the revised regulation. The resolution also stressed that the current procedural framework under Article 226 TFEU does not oblige the Council and Commission to negotiate, but Parliament insisted they resume talks based on a revised proposal reflecting legal consultations and practical experience, while invoking the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making to demand structured negotiations. The text was forwarded to EU institutions and national parliaments to reinforce accountability demands.

title: Differentiated integration: REPORT on differentiated integration
background: The European Union's increasing use of differentiated integration mechanisms, such as enhanced cooperation and permanent structured cooperation, alongside debates on balancing unity with flexibility, prompted by the 2017 Commission White Paper and challenges like Brexit. The Parliament will discuss differentiated integration's implications for EU governance and cohesion.

stances.stance:
SD strongly sanctions the issue’s endorsement of multispeed integration, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to pragmatic EU advancement while preserving unity, as exemplified by Jo Leinen’s emphasis on enabling proactive states without excluding others.  
SD approves the issue’s push to replace unanimity with qualified majority voting via Article 48(7) TEU, a reform SD has long advocated to overcome deadlocks in taxation and economic governance.  
SD proposes amending Clause 12 to include a sunset clause for all temporary differentiated measures, ensuring they automatically expire after five years unless renewed by unanimous consent, thereby strengthening safeguards against fragmentation.  
SD endorses the issue’s rejection of permanent opt-outs, emphasizing that transitional periods for new members must adhere to strict timelines, a stance consistent with SD’s vision of an equitable and cohesive Union.  
SD applauds the call to integrate intergovernmental mechanisms like the ESM into EU law, which aligns with SD’s priority to enhance democratic accountability and institutional transparency.

ECR rejects fundamentally the issue's prohibition of permanent opt-outs, which contradicts their commitment to national sovereignty and voluntary cooperation frameworks.  
ECR opposes the integration of intergovernmental mechanisms like the ESM into EU legal structures, viewing this as unacceptable centralization eroding member state autonomy.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of economic asymmetry, failing to protect states like Greece from punitive integration timelines that exacerbate inequality among members.  
ECR opposes the push for qualified majority voting in taxation, which fully challenges with their defense of unanimous decision-making to preserve national fiscal sovereignty.  
The issue’s rejection of differentiation in social policies disregards ECR’s stance that member states must retain exclusive competence to avoid homogenized EU overreach.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined principles regarding differentiated integration within the EU, emphasizing its pragmatic but cautious use to avoid fragmentation while promoting inclusivity and deeper unity. It acknowledged differentiated integration as an existing reality, encompassing multispeed approaches, variable geometry, and à la carte mechanisms, but stressed it must remain temporary, open to all Member States, and aligned with Treaty provisions (Articles 20 and 46 TEU) to prevent creating first- and second-class members. The resolution called for shifting Council voting from unanimity to qualified majority voting via the passerelle clause (Article 48(7) TEU) to overcome deadlocks, particularly in taxation and economic governance, and highlighted Brexit as an opportunity to transition from opt-out to non-discriminatory opt-in models. It urged integrating initiatives like the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) into the EU legal framework, completing the Banking Union with a fiscal backstop, and establishing a Euro Area budget line. The Parliament emphasized democratic accountability, opposing intergovernmental structures that reduce transparency, and demanded strengthened parliamentary oversight over EU expenditure, including enhanced cooperation activities. It advocated ending permanent opt-outs in primary law, allowing only temporary, case-by-case transitional periods for new members, and proposed partnerships for non-EU states adhering to EU values and contributing to the budget. Core EU policies on fundamental rights, economic cohesion, and environmental standards were deemed non-negotiable, with differentiation prohibited in areas risking negative externalities like social dumping. The resolution also promoted regional cooperation, cross-border initiatives, and rationalizing budgetary tools to support convergence, while urging the Commission to enforce single market rules and accelerate socio-economic integration.

title: OLAF Supervisory Committee's annual report 2014: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the OLAF Supervisory Committee’s annual report 2014
background: The OLAF Supervisory Committee's 2014 report identified procedural non-compliance in case openings, insufficient implementation of oversight recommendations, and resource allocation concerns within the European Anti-Fraud Office. Institutional tensions arose over supervisory access to operational data and secretariat independence under Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 883/2013. The Parliament will discuss OLAF's adherence to investigative protocols and oversight mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly advocates the issue's condemnation of OLAF's systemic procedural violations, perfectly aligning with its principle that EU agencies must exemplify legal compliance when handling taxpayer funds.  
EPP perfectly aligns with demands for immediate SC mandate strengthening, particularly full case file access and independent secretariat control, as critical to restoring institutional credibility in fraud prevention.  
EPP fully supports the issue's exposure of OLAF's statistical manipulation, viewing enhanced SC oversight as essential to prevent politically motivated investigation metrics.  
EPP endorses without reservation the call to abolish arbitrary financial indicators in IPPs, recognizing this as vital to refocusing OLAF on substantive fraud patterns rather than bureaucratic performance quotas.  
EPP perfectly aligns with demands for transparent resource reallocation, particularly rebalancing investigator distribution to match actual fraud risks in agricultural funds versus tobacco enforcement.

SD rejects the issue's procedural foundation for violating due process principles by excluding OLAF's input during critical debates.  
SD opposes fundamentally the one-sided condemnation of OLAF's operations without verifying claims against its 2014 annual report, contradicting SD's insistence on evidence-based policymaking.  
SD condemns the issue's failure to address the Supervisory Committee's overreach into operational matters, which undermines OLAF's investigative independence central to SD's anti-fraud priorities.  
SD highlights the issue's disregard for balanced institutional scrutiny, ignoring SD's core demand for equal treatment of EU bodies through simultaneous review of OLAF and SC reports.  
SD denounces the premature resource allocation criticisms as inconsistent with SD's data-driven approach to budgetary oversight, given incomplete case closure statistics from 2012-2014.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over systemic deficiencies in the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF), particularly regarding the improper opening of 423 cases in 2012 without prior assessment of fraud suspicions, as required by Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 883/2013, with only 8.4% of closed cases resulting in recommendations. It criticized OLAF’s lack of compliance with the OLAF Supervisory Committee (SC), noting that only 8 out of 50 SC recommendations were fully implemented, and highlighted the SC’s inability to effectively monitor OLAF’s independence, procedural guarantees, and investigation durations due to insufficient information access. The resolution condemned OLAF’s failure to incorporate SC feedback into its 2015 Investigation Policy Priorities (IPPs), including abolishing financial indicators without stakeholder consultation, and expressed concerns over resource allocation, with 33% of investigators handling agricultural and structural funds (86% of €1.9 billion at risk) versus 10% assigned to tobacco and counterfeit units. It urged OLAF to justify non-implementation of SC recommendations, improve transparency in its participation in Commission ‘Clearing House’ meetings, and comply with legal requirements on investigation timelines. The Parliament called on the Commission to strengthen the SC’s mandate by amending Working Arrangements by 31 December 2015, ensuring the SC’s Secretariat operates independently, with full access to case files and authority over staffing and budget. Additionally, it demanded OLAF provide the SC with data on complaints and their resolution, while acknowledging initial improvements in OLAF-SC collaboration on prolonged investigations.

title: e-Democracy in the EU: potential and challenges: REPORT on e-democracy in the European Union: potential and challenges
background: Declining EU voter turnout, digital technology advancements, and existing treaties on democratic governance prompted consideration of ICT's role in civic participation. Cybersecurity concerns, digital divides, and Estonia's 2005 e-voting implementation highlighted challenges. The Parliament will discuss e-democracy's potential to enhance democratic engagement and institutional transparency within the EU framework.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on e-administration and open-source solutions as critical tools for transparent governance, aligning perfectly with their commitment to participatory democracy.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing cybersecurity safeguards for any e-voting trials to ensure verifiable secrecy and auditability, building on Estonia’s model while addressing current technical limitations.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on smart city applications and accessibility for persons with reduced mobility, which effectively advances their priority of inclusive, localized decision-making.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports the issue’s digital inclusion measures—affordable internet access and literacy programs—as foundational steps toward equitable e-participation.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that phased implementation of e-democracy tools must prioritize data protection frameworks, consistent with their longstanding advocacy for digital rights.

ECR rejects the issue's failure to address systemic media suppression undermining democratic participation, as evidenced by state-funded Greek media excluding opposition voices.  
ECR opposes fundamentally any e-democracy framework that does not first guarantee impartial access to public broadcasting resources for all political groups.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of media accountability by permitting EU-funded platforms to perpetuate ideological exclusion of conservative representatives.  
ECR condemns the issue's silence on preventing member states from weaponizing EU infrastructure like parliamentary studios for partisan censorship.  
This firmly conflicts with ECR's position that technological democratization requires prior enforcement of Article 11 Charter freedoms against national media monopolies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over declining political engagement and voter turnout, notably the 42.54% participation in the 2014 EU elections, amid crises eroding trust in EU institutions. It emphasized e-democracy’s potential to enhance transparency, accountability, and citizen participation through ICT tools like e-voting, e-consultation, and e-decision-making, while stressing these must complement, not replace, representative democracy. Key proposals included expanding secure e-voting systems, citing Estonia’s 2005 precedent, and addressing cybersecurity, data protection, and digital divides by ensuring affordable high-speed internet access, digital literacy programs, and multilingual platforms. The resolution urged EU institutions and member states to prioritize e-government services, open data, and pilot projects like crowdsourcing, while promoting gender equality in ICT and political processes. It called for a European Charter of Internet Rights to safeguard net neutrality, privacy, and freedom of expression, and highlighted the need for critical media literacy to counter misinformation. The Parliament also advocated leveraging EU programs like Erasmus+ and Horizon 2020 to foster active citizenship, and recommended revising the European Citizens’ Initiative to streamline digital participation, including e-IDAS for signature collection. Overall, the resolution underscored balancing technological innovation with safeguards to strengthen democratic legitimacy and inclusivity across the EU.

title: European Citizens' Initiative: REPORT on the European Citizens’ Initiative
background: The European Citizens’ Initiative, established under the 2009 Lisbon Treaty to enable public legislative proposals, faced implementation challenges since 2012, including low success rates, technical barriers for organizers, and criticism of the Commission’s admissibility assessments. The Parliament will discuss enhancing the initiative’s effectiveness and accessibility for EU citizens.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to mandate binding legislative action on successful initiatives, totally conflicting with their demand for direct citizen impact  
GREEN_EFA opposes the maintained procedural barriers to ECI admissibility as perpetuating institutional detachment from grassroots democratic efforts  
GREEN_EFA condemns the absence of enforceable deadlines for Commission responses to validated initiatives, overlooking critical accountability mechanisms  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally disputes the issue's tolerance of Commission discretion in initiative rejections, inconsistent with transparency principles  
GREEN_EFA challenges the limited scope of technical improvements as inadequate to reverse citizen disillusionment documented in 53 failed initiatives

SD entirely advocates the issue’s call to lower the minimum participation age to 16, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to empowering youth engagement in democratic processes.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand to simplify data collection requirements, eliminating personal ID barriers to enhance accessibility for all citizens.  
SD entirely advocates decoupling registration from signature collection start dates, ensuring organizers can mobilize support without procedural delays.  
SD perfectly aligns with the proposal for institutional accountability, requiring the Commission to provide legislative follow-up within 12 months for admissible initiatives.  
SD entirely advocates enhanced financial and technical support for organizers, including centralized platforms and free translation, advancing SD’s priority of inclusive participatory democracy.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the implementation challenges and shortcomings of the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI), a participatory democracy tool enabling citizens to propose legislation by collecting one million signatures from at least seven Member States. Despite over six million citizens participating in 51 initiatives since 2012, only three—Right2Water, One of Us, and Stop Vivisection—were deemed admissible, with six rejected initiatives challenged in court, highlighting procedural and legal barriers. Key issues included complex data requirements, lack of user-friendly IT tools, insufficient public awareness, and rigid admissibility checks by the Commission, which faced criticism for potential conflicts of interest. The resolution called for revising Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 to simplify processes, lower the minimum participation age to 16, standardize data collection (removing personal ID requirements), extend the 12-month signature period, and decouple registration from the collection start date. It urged enhanced support through free translation, a centralized online platform, financial assistance, and improved Commission guidance to organizers. The Parliament emphasized the need for transparency, institutional accountability, and public hearings, while advocating for clearer rejection reasoning, partial registration of initiatives, and post-submission legislative follow-up within 12 months. Strengthening interinstitutional cooperation, leveraging digital tools, and addressing liability concerns for organizers were also prioritized to revitalize the ECI’s role in bridging citizens and EU policymaking.

title: Ombudsman’s strategic inquiry OI/2/2017 on the transparency of legislative discussions in the preparatory bodies of the Council of the EU: REPORT on the Ombudsman’s strategic inquiry OI/2/2017 on the transparency of legislative discussions in the preparatory bodies of the Council of the EU
background: The European Ombudsman’s 2017 inquiry identified insufficient transparency in the EU Council’s legislative preparatory bodies, citing maladministration and non-response to recommendations. The Parliament will discuss Council legislative process transparency, particularly document access and preparatory body deliberations, under Treaty obligations on institutional openness.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue’s demand for live-streamed Council preparatory meetings, aligning perfectly with their decades-long advocacy for EU institutional transparency.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the call to abolish LIMITE classifications, emphasizing this directly addresses the democratic deficit they’ve campaigned against since the Lisbon Treaty.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening Article 4 by mandating real-time publication of Member State position papers to empower national parliaments’ oversight capacities.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on transforming the Council into a public legislative chamber, a reform matching their 2024 manifesto pledge to “replace closed-door diplomacy with open lawmaking.”  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s critical timing ahead of elections, noting its potential to combat misinformation through transparency—a core GREEN_EFA principle since 1999.

ECR rejects fundamentally the issue's imposition of EU transparency frameworks on intergovernmental bodies like the Eurogroup, which violates the principle of national sovereignty in fiscal policy coordination.  
ECR opposes the systematic publication of Member States’ negotiating positions as it would destabilize diplomatic dialogue and expose sensitive compromises to populist distortions.  
This issue conflicts with ECR's stance that consensus-based decision-making preserves equality among nations, rejecting qualified majority voting as a tool to marginalize smaller states.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as the necessity for confidential preparatory discussions to achieve pragmatic legislative outcomes without external interference.  
ECR objects to live-streaming Council working group meetings, arguing it would performative transparency undermine substantive negotiations and incentivize political grandstanding.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the Council of the EU’s lack of transparency in legislative processes, particularly in its preparatory bodies like Coreper and over 150 working groups, which often operate behind closed doors, undermining democratic accountability. It criticized the Council’s failure to proactively publish legislative documents, reliance on the unjustified ‘LIMITE’ classification to restrict access, and refusal to systematically record or disclose Member States’ positions, hindering public scrutiny and enabling governments to evade responsibility for EU decisions. The resolution endorsed the European Ombudsman’s findings of maladministration and urged the Council to implement recommendations, including public access to meetings via live-streaming, publishing minutes, aligning practices with CJEU rulings, and ending opaque consensus-based decision-making instead of using qualified majority voting. It highlighted the imbalance in transparency between Parliament’s open procedures and the Council’s secretive practices, stressing the need for equivalent standards to combat misinformation and strengthen public trust, especially ahead of the 2019 elections. The Parliament also demanded formalizing informal bodies like the Eurogroup under EU transparency rules, transforming the Council into a transparent legislative chamber, and ensuring trilogues adhere to public mandates and document disclosure. It emphasized that systemic opacity in the Council contradicts Treaty obligations and democratic principles, eroding citizen confidence in the EU.

title: Outcome of the referendum in the United Kingdom: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the decision to leave the EU resulting from the UK referendum
background: The United Kingdom's 2016 EU membership referendum resulted in a majority vote to leave, creating unprecedented institutional uncertainty. Pre-existing EU challenges included economic disparities, migration pressures, and debates over integration levels, while Article 50 TEU established withdrawal procedures. The Parliament will discuss managing the UK's departure process and addressing broader EU reform priorities.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the issue's demand for immediate Article 50 activation as punitive haste inconsistent with democratic negotiation principles.  
EFDD completely rejects the issue's call for deeper EU integration, which perpetuates the undemocratic "political union" model criticized in debates.  
EFDD condemns the nullification of the February 2016 settlement as evidence of Brussels' refusal to address institutional overreach.  
EFDD highlights the issue's failure to acknowledge EU responsibility for migration mismanagement and economic policies creating "massive divisions" cited by Farage.  
EFDD declares the reform roadmap incompatible with their vision of "global ambitions" through national sovereignty rather than Lisbon Treaty centralization.

SD strongly upholds the immediate activation of Article 50, aligning with the issue’s urgency to prevent economic destabilization while emphasizing solidarity with pro-EU British youth and universities benefiting from Erasmus+ programs.  

SD approves the issue’s demand for EU reform prioritizing social justice, proposing enhanced public investment mechanisms beyond the current Juncker Plan to address inequality gaps exposed by Brexit-driven discontent.  

SD endorses nullifying the February 2016 EU-UK settlement as vital to resetting negotiations but suggests explicitly linking future UK market access to adherence to EU social standards to prevent regulatory dumping.  

SD advocates amending the fiscal compact through treaty revisions to allow greater fiscal flexibility for social investments, converting criticism of austerity into actionable reform proposals within the issue’s framework.  

SD emphasizes accelerating tax justice measures by implementing TAXE committee recommendations within 12 months, framing this as critical to restoring citizen trust in line with the issue’s anti-evasion priorities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the imperative to respect the UK’s decision to leave the EU, urging immediate activation of Article 50 to begin withdrawal negotiations, and called on the UK Prime Minister to formally notify the European Council by its June 28-29 meeting to prevent damaging uncertainty. It declared the February 2016 EU-UK settlement null and void, emphasized that future UK-EU relations cannot precede the withdrawal agreement, and stressed Parliament’s role in consenting to and overseeing negotiations. The resolution demanded EU reform to prioritize citizens’ interests, strengthen core institutions like the Economic and Monetary Union, freedom, security, justice, and foreign policy, while avoiding à la carte integration. It proposed a roadmap leveraging the Lisbon Treaty, supported by Parliament’s reports on institutional adjustments and Eurozone budgetary capacity, and mandated internal reorganization to reflect the UK’s departure, including reallocating the UK Commissioner’s portfolio and adjusting Council Presidencies to safeguard EU operations. The resolution underscored the need for democratic renewal to address challenges like migration, economic instability, and social inequality, ensuring the EU delivers tangible benefits to citizens.

title: Guidelines on the framework of future EU-UK relations: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the framework of the future EU-UK relationship
background: Following the United Kingdom’s 2017 Article 50 TEU notification to withdraw from the EU, negotiations addressed citizens’ rights, financial obligations, and Northern Ireland border arrangements, culminating in the December 2017 Joint Report and February 2018 draft Withdrawal Agreement. The Parliament will discuss the framework for future EU-UK relations, including transitional arrangements and post-Brexit cooperation.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the issue's insistence on CJEU jurisdiction and regulatory alignment, totally disputeing with ENF's commitment to national sovereignty and opposition to supranational legal overreach.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of mutual trade interests by prioritizing protectionist measures, inconsistent with ENF's advocacy for tariff-free agreements without EU interference.  
ENF opposes the Northern Ireland Protocol framework as unnecessary EU meddling, asserting that bilateral solutions between the UK and Ireland align with their principle of intergovernmental cooperation.  
The issue's demand for continued EU budgetary compliance and financial transfers contradicts ENF's stance against economic subjugation to EU structures post-Brexit.  
ENF fundamentally disputes the premise of punitive level playing field provisions, viewing them as punitive tools rather than fair competition measures, in direct opposition to their free-market principles.

GREEN_EFA completely supports the issue’s emphasis on maintaining regulatory alignment through the Northern Ireland Protocol, perfectly aligning with their longstanding commitment to upholding the Good Friday Agreement and preventing a hard border.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand for strict adherence to EU tax avoidance and money laundering standards, recognizing this as essential to preserving fair competition post-Brexit.  
GREEN_EFA completely supports the issue’s provisions for lifelong residency and non-discrimination protections, effectively advancing their priority of maintaining EU citizenship rights for UK residents through residence-based entitlements.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s preparedness measures for all Brexit scenarios, including economic safeguards that reflect their warnings about diminished prosperity from ideological-driven separation.  
GREEN_EFA completely supports the issue’s framework for sustainable fisheries management and coastal community protections, mirroring their demands to prevent Brexit-related damage to maritime economies like Galicia and Scotland.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the necessity of establishing a comprehensive framework for the future EU-UK relationship following Brexit, emphasizing the importance of an association agreement under Articles 8 TEU and 217 TFEU to ensure flexible cooperation across trade, foreign policy, security, and thematic areas. It stressed that the UK, as a third country, must maintain regulatory alignment with EU standards, including adherence to CJEU jurisdiction, level playing field provisions on taxation, environmental protection, labor rights, and data protection equivalence, while excluding cherry-picking of single market benefits. The resolution highlighted the need to protect citizens’ rights reciprocally, ensuring lifelong residency, family reunification, and non-discrimination for EU citizens in the UK and vice versa, rejecting the UK’s proposed differentiation between pre- and post-transition arrivals. It endorsed the Northern Ireland Protocol to avoid a hard border, upholding the Good Friday Agreement through continued regulatory alignment or specific solutions. Transitional arrangements were deemed critical to prolong EU acquis application, preventing a "cliff-edge" exit, with the UK bound by international agreements during this period but barred from new trade deals until its conclusion. The Parliament underscored preparedness for all scenarios, including no-deal, urging institutions and citizens to mitigate disruptions. It welcomed the Commission’s draft Withdrawal Agreement (28 February 2018) but insisted on robust governance, dispute mechanisms, and CJEU oversight, while conditioning future cooperation on strict compliance with EU principles and budgetary rules, excluding net financial transfers to the UK.

title: European citizens’ initiative: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European citizens’ initiative

The Parliament will discuss revising the initiative’s regulatory framework to address accessibility and procedural barriers hindering citizen participation.

title: General revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure: REPORT on the general revision of Parliament's Rules of Procedure
background: The European Parliament's Rules of Procedure required updates to align with the 2016 Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making, address evolving legislative practices, and modernize operational frameworks amid calls for enhanced transparency, ethical accountability, and procedural efficiency. The Parliament will discuss a comprehensive revision of its internal governance rules to streamline legislative processes and institutional integrity standards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised amendments to its Rules of Procedure to enhance legislative efficiency, transparency, and accountability, aligning with the 2016 Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making. Key changes included mandating the Secretary-General to adapt IT systems for tracking written questions, deleting Rule 106(4) once regulatory scrutiny procedures are phased out, and revising the Code of Conduct for legislative negotiations. Transparency measures required Members to update financial interest declarations within six months, prohibited paid lobbying roles, introduced stricter verification of declarations, and mandated former MEPs to inform Parliament of new lobbying positions. Lobbying rules were tightened, including badge removal for non-compliance and banning entourage badges for lobbying. Procedural reforms streamlined voting sequences, limited written questions to 20 per MEP every three months (addressing over 60,000 annual submissions), capped motions for resolutions to one per member monthly, restricted roll-call votes to 100 per group per session, and proposed abolishing written declarations or requiring 40 MEPs from three groups to table them. Thresholds for initiatives were set at one-twentieth, one-tenth, or one-fifth of Parliament’s membership. Intergroups were required to operate transparently, and committees gained authority to accelerate priority legislation. The Commission was obligated to respond to parliamentary initiatives within three months or face committee scrutiny, and withdrawals of proposals required consultation with Parliament. Amendments entered force at the next session, except Rule 212(2) on delegations, effective after the 2019 elections.

title: Interinstitutional agreement on Better law-making: REPORT on the conclusion of an Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission
background: The 2003 Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making, predating the EU’s 2003 enlargement and Lisbon Treaty reforms, faced calls for revision to align with post-Treaty legislative frameworks, address evolving regulatory practices, and consolidate institutional cooperation standards. The Parliament will discuss negotiating a new agreement to modernize interinstitutional legislative processes and regulatory efficiency.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to modernize the 2003 Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making to align with post-Lisbon Treaty frameworks, enhance transparency, and strengthen cooperation among EU institutions. It welcomed the provisional agreement on a new Interinstitutional Agreement (IIA) aimed at improving legislative quality, multiannual programming, and annual Commission Work Programme consultations, while safeguarding Parliament’s legislative powers and right of initiative. Key provisions include enhanced impact assessments overseen by an independent Regulatory Scrutiny Board (without veto power), measures to reduce administrative burdens—particularly for SMEs—through an Annual Burden Survey, and commitments to simplify legislation and repeal obsolete acts. The resolution emphasized the need for balanced criteria to distinguish delegated and implementing acts under Articles 290 and 291 TFEU, urging swift alignment of existing laws with Lisbon Treaty provisions. It stressed transparency in legislative procedures, advocating for second-reading agreements as the standard and cautioning against non-transparent first-reading negotiations. The agreement also promotes cooperation with national parliaments on subsidiarity checks, flexibility in enforcing the eight-week deadline for reasoned opinions, and improved political dialogue. The Parliament highlighted the importance of evaluating the new IIA’s impact on existing agreements, ensuring compliance with deadlines, and adapting its Rules of Procedure to reflect the agreement. Specific operational details included timelines for objections to delegated acts (two months, extendable by two months) and urgency procedures for crises, alongside requirements for Commission consultations with Member State experts and stakeholders during delegated act preparation. The resolution concluded with calls for rigorous implementation and future technical follow-up on unresolved issues, such as international agreement procedures and delegated act criteria.

title: Regulations and general conditions governing the performance of the Ombudsman’s duties (Statute of the European Ombudsman): REPORT on a draft regulation of the European Parliament laying down the regulations and general conditions governing the performance of the Ombudsman’s duties (Statute of the European Ombudsman) and repealing Decision 94/262/ECSC, EC, Euratom
background: The European Ombudsman’s mandate, established under pre-Lisbon Treaty rules (Decision 94/262/ECSC, EC, Euratom), required alignment with post-2009 legal frameworks, including Article 228 TFEU and the Charter of Fundamental Rights’ right to good administration. The Parliament will discuss updating the Ombudsman’s regulations to reflect institutional reforms and enhance oversight of EU administrative practices.

stances.stance:

SD highlights the Ombudsman’s authority to access classified documents and coordinate with the European Public Prosecutor’s Office as a vital step toward combating financial fraud, mirroring SD’s anti-corruption manifesto pledges.  
SD emphasizes that the three-year complaint window and confidentiality safeguards perfectly align with SD’s longstanding advocacy for citizen-centric justice and procedural fairness in EU governance.  
 SD underscores the budgetary autonomy and institutional cooperation mechanisms as essential to fulfilling the Ombudsman’s expanded role, directly advancing SD’s vision of a democratically robust EU.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to modernize the role and operational framework of the European Ombudsman by adopting a new regulation to replace the outdated 1994 Decision, aligning it with post-Lisbon Treaty legal standards. The regulation strengthens the Ombudsman’s mandate to investigate maladministration in EU institutions, bodies, and agencies (excluding the Court of Justice in its judicial role), emphasizing the right to good administration under the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. It grants the Ombudsman authority to conduct own-initiative inquiries to address systemic issues, follow up on compliance with recommendations, and submit annual reports to Parliament assessing institutional compliance and resource adequacy. Complaints must be filed within three years of the complainant becoming aware of the issue, after exhausting administrative remedies, and can remain confidential. The Ombudsman has broad access to information, including classified documents, subject to confidentiality agreements, and must notify relevant authorities (e.g., the European Public Prosecutor’s Office) of potential criminal matters while respecting due process rights. Institutions are required to respond to inquiries within three months (extendable by two months) and cooperate fully, with non-compliance reported to Parliament. The Ombudsman’s independence is safeguarded through appointment by Parliament for the parliamentary term, with qualifications mirroring judicial standards, and a budget ensuring operational autonomy. The regulation also mandates cooperation with national ombudsmen and EU bodies like the Fundamental Rights Agency, while ensuring staff confidentiality and procedural safeguards for handling sensitive data.

title: Implementation of the Treaty provisions concerning enhanced cooperation: REPORT on the implementation of the Treaty provisions concerning enhanced cooperation
background: The EU’s post-Lisbon Treaty framework enabled enhanced cooperation as a last-resort integration tool, with prior use in justice, patent, and fiscal policy areas. Studies (2017-2018) highlighted procedural challenges, including unanimity requirements and unclear operational guidelines, prompting institutional review. The Parliament will discuss enhanced cooperation’s implementation, institutional effectiveness, and Treaty-aligned reforms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and recommendations regarding the use of enhanced cooperation in the EU, emphasizing its role as a last-resort mechanism under Article 20 TEU to advance integration when unanimity cannot be achieved. It highlighted that enhanced cooperation, requiring at least nine Member States, has been underutilized but proven effective in areas like divorce law, property regimes (18 participating states as of 2019), the European Patent, and the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO), which involves 22 Member States and aims to combat EU budget fraud by late 2020. The resolution noted challenges, including lengthy procedures due to unclear timelines, lack of operational guidelines, and reliance on intergovernmental agreements outside EU frameworks (e.g., the Fiscal Compact), which undermine legal consistency and democratic scrutiny. It urged activating Article 333 TFEU to switch from unanimity to qualified majority voting (QMV) post-authorization, enhancing parliamentary oversight via stronger roles for the European Parliament and national/regional legislatures, and clarifying rules for Member State withdrawal or expulsion. The resolution called for EU budget alignment with enhanced cooperation costs, CJEU jurisdiction, and a Commission unit to streamline coordination. It stressed integrating enhanced cooperation into the *acquis communautaire* and urged Treaty revisions to address gaps, including sub-national entities’ roles. Specific to the EPPO, Parliament urged non-participating states to join, emphasized cooperation with OLAF and Eurojust, and supported potential mandate expansion to counter-terrorism. Overall, the resolution advocated preserving the EU’s institutional framework while using enhanced cooperation pragmatically to overcome deadlocks, ensuring transparency, inclusivity, and legal coherence.

title: Implementation of the Treaty provisions concerning national Parliaments: REPORT on the implementation of the Treaty provisions concerning national parliaments
background: The Treaty of Lisbon (2009) expanded national parliaments’ roles in EU governance, including subsidiarity oversight via Protocols 1 and 2, with periodic evaluations through Commission reports and interparliamentary initiatives. A 2015 multi-state parliamentary declaration and 2017 Court of Justice rulings on mixed agreements underscored institutional developments. The Parliament will discuss national parliaments’ implementation of Treaty-mandated functions in EU legislative and democratic processes.

It stressed the importance of proportional representation of political minorities in national parliamentary opinions and urged reforms to strengthen parliamentary oversight of EU trade agreements and fiscal policies, while opposing a "red card" procedure as incompatible with current treaty frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about challenges in effectively overseeing the European Commission due to the Treaties' lack of a clear definition of the EU's "executive," which is fragmented across EU, national, and regional levels and varies by policy area (e.g., Commission for exclusive competences, Council for CFSP). It stressed the importance of the Spitzenkandidaten process for politicizing the Commission and enhancing democratic legitimacy but warned against reduced oversight. Key recommendations included strengthening parliamentary tools like budgetary discharge (noting 80% of EU funds are jointly managed with Member States), improving transparency in delegated/implementing acts (with 716 performance indicators cited), and fostering interinstitutional cooperation to extend scrutiny to the Council’s budget. The resolution urged Treaty reforms to enable individual Commissioner accountability, streamline executive definitions, and lower censure thresholds while maintaining institutional balance. It also called for enhanced cooperation with national parliaments and criticized the Commission’s administrative lapses, particularly in appointing its Secretary-General, urging rule-abiding procedures.

title: Negotiations with the United Kingdom following its notification that it intends to withdraw from the European Union: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on negotiations with the United Kingdom following its notification that it intends to withdraw from the European Union

This unprecedented departure required negotiations on withdrawal terms, addressing legal obligations, financial settlements, and territorial implications under EU law. The Parliament will discuss the framework for EU-UK negotiations following the Article 50 notification.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the unprecedented nature of the UK’s withdrawal from the EU, emphasizing the need for an orderly process to minimize disruption to citizens, legal entities, and European integration. It stressed that negotiations must prioritize the interests of EU-27 citizens, including protecting the rights of EU citizens in the UK and UK citizens in the EU-27 through reciprocity, non-discrimination, and adherence to EU law, including the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The resolution highlighted the UK’s obligation to fulfill all financial commitments, including multiannual budgetary liabilities and contingent costs, and underscored the unique challenges facing Ireland, urging measures to avoid a hard border and preserve the Good Friday Agreement. It rejected any sectoral or preferential access for the UK to the single market post-withdrawal, noting that future agreements must respect EU autonomy, values, and legal order, with possible frameworks under Article 217 TFEU for a balanced association. Transitional arrangements were limited to three years, requiring strict symmetry and oversight by the Court of Justice. The Parliament also called for urgent relocation of EU agencies (e.g., European Banking Authority) and adjustments to EU law, while reaffirming its veto power over any withdrawal agreement and future relationship deals. It regretted the UK’s rejection of single market membership but asserted that non-member status precludes equivalent benefits, urging reflection on EU reforms to strengthen integration post-Brexit.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of strengthening democratic legitimacy and transparency in the EU by endorsing amendments to the Framework Agreement with the Commission, particularly focusing on the 'Spitzenkandidaten' process for electing the Commission President. It emphasized that this process, used successfully in 2014, ensures citizens’ direct influence by requiring European political parties to nominate lead candidates before elections, aligning with Article 17(7) TEU. It highlighted that allowing Commissioners to campaign in European elections without resigning—mirroring national practices—enhances democratic engagement but requires safeguards to ensure impartiality, confidentiality, and a prohibition on using Commission resources for campaigns. The Parliament called for revising the Code of Conduct for Commissioners to include a three-year cooling-off period post-tenure, stricter transparency measures, and alignment with Parliament’s earlier resolutions on ethics and integrity. title: Role of cities in the institutional framework of the Union: REPORT on the role of cities in the institutional framework of the Union
